We booked a standard room and were very happy with it. The bed was very comfortable, the bathroom huge and well-appointed, and we arrived home every day to find a bowl of fresh fruit on our table. The best part of the room were the windows, which flung wide to a breathtaking view of the Bosphorus, and allowed the sounds of waves lapping at the coast to enter the room at all hours. The staff was very friendly and helpful at all times, and even though we found the hotel's boat to be rather superfluous (it doesn't take you where you need to go, and doesn't go anywhere at convenient times), the local Cengelkoy ferry station was just a short walk down the road, and once we figured out the ferry schedule, we were good to go - the ferries were easy, convenient and cheap, and will take you right to Eminonu, where you can board the tram to Sultanahmet. And you get to enjoy the beautiful scenery along the Bosphorus at the same time! We found that all the public transportation in Istanbul is easy to use and inexpensive. The cafe at the restaurant serves decent food, but it is VERY pricey. The breakfast is extensive and delicious, and they will make you eggs upon request. The Sumahan is a great place for a quiet retreat from the hustle and bustle of Istanbul - at the end of our trip, we spent a night in Sultanahmet. It was nice, but if I went back to Istabul, I wouldn't hesitate to book the Sumahan again.

Reviews.Title: “fantastic boutique hotel on edge of the Bosphorus”
Reviews.Author: greatweekends
Reviews.Content: We had a fantastic stay in this hotel. We stayed in one of the suites, which had a beautiful view across, up and down the bosphorus. The suites have patio doors onto the lawn, which goes down to the water edge. We ate breakfast each day outside on the water edge. The bosphorus is within a few metres of the suite and there is so much going on you can just sit there and watch the world go by. The food was excellent - not the wide variety you would get in a big central city hotel but simple tasty local produce prepared and served well. The suite itself was spacious and had excellent facilities. Several people have commented that the hotel is some way from the old part of Istanbul - yes it is but its great fun to get to the old city either by the hotel boat and then either bus taxi or tram or to walk about 200m to the local ferry station. You can then experience real life on the ferry at a cost of about 50 pence (1$) for the trip right into the old city. Next to the hotel and on the edge of the Bosphorus is a fish restaurant where we ate several times. The starters were superb and overall the food excellent. We had no issues with the service levels - staff were discrete but there when needed. Istanbul is a great place but watch out for taxi drivers and all the stallholders - they will rip you off given the chance. If you look around and barter enough there are bargains to be had. Overall a great fun time.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect Honeymoon Hotel”
Reviews.Author: ikepod
Reviews.Content: On the asian side of Turkey. Perfect if you have time to spend crossing the bosphorous river in the morning to the european side about 20 min. One of the best hotel experiences I had. Not very good english speaking crew.

Reviews.Title: “Sumahan - beautiful but remote from hub of Istanbul”
Reviews.Author: lisamariaManchester
Reviews.Content: We spent 3 nights at the Sumahan. Beware - Taxi drivers at airport may not know its location. Ours headed straight across the river when our airport was on the asian side of Istanbul where the hotel is located. The hotel itself is beautiful and the rooms comfortable - we did not experience the same problems one reviewer had with the air con and the quality of bedding.We found the bed extremely comfortable. The views from the room were amazing - the best view I've ever had at any hotel (all rooms have a river view). Gorkhan the Manager was wonderful - extremely pleasant and helpful and spoke excellent english (although it is true that some staff have problems with speaking english). The downsides of the hotel were that the evening meal we ate there was extremely overpriced and quite unimpressive. I don't expect to be served macdonalds style chips paying those kind of prices! The drinks were very expensive too. There are no other bar alternatives that we managed to find near the hotel, or licensed restaurants as it on the asian, therefore predominantly muslim. side of the river. We did, however, find a shop selling wine, beers ,etc on the night we ate at the hotel and didn't stay out in the sultanamet area. This was a much cheaper alternative to staying in the hotel restaurant and we enjoyed watching the river from our room instead. Getting into the throng of things was a bit of a hassle. While the hotel offers a complementary service, we never used this as it set off at 9am in the morning (too early for us) and came back at two fixed times that didn't really suit our movements. It is possible to catch the Cenglekoy ferry, or take a taxi from the hotel to another ferry stop (ask Gorkhan) as cheaper alternatives to a taxi door -to -door. We did enjoy our ferry rides on the river with the amazing views, it has to be said and they are much, much cheaper than taxis (agree prices ,on paper as taxi drivers are unlikely to speak english -or pretend not to, beforehand to prevent getting ripped off). Ferrys from Sultanamet coming back to Cenglekoy stop at about 7.30pm so you need to get taxis if staying for a night out. So, a lovely place to stay, but remote from main hub of Istanbul!

Reviews.Title: “Motel bedding is not luxury”
Reviews.Author: jackifus
Reviews.Content: We booked three nights stay in the Sumahan based on the beautiful website and the reviews here. We stayed only one night. We found the hotel lovely to look at - with gorgeous views. The pictures are absolutely accurate. What one does not see in the pictures is very relevant to your comfort however. -Substandard bedding quality. The duvet and pillows are made of a synthetic fiber-fill material that feels spongey and doesn't breathe. American motels provide better quality bedding. -The air conditioning in our room did not function. The room faced the river - which was lovely, but it also means that the room heats up dramatically in the afternoon sun. Without air conditioning, the air was humid and very hot, enough such that we were sweating while sitting still. -Substandard Problem Resolution. We reported the air conditioning problem upon check-in. We were told that nothing could be done. A hotel that provided service would have placed a fan in the room at a minimum. Instead, we returned from dinner to find that the staff had been testing the unit, and left it on full heat by mistake. -Inadequate staff training. Hotel staff other than the front desk have absolutely no ability to communicate even rudimentarily in English. I don't expect fluency - I do expect a staff-member who provides a service to me (ironing a shirt), to be able to understand payment methods - such as "charge it to the room". Instead, the fellow appeared not to understand the concept, just holding out his hand waiting for cash. He accepted $20 US dollars as I had no other cash. This isn't standard hotel service. -Peculiar room design. The visual design of the room is pleasing, however the layout failed to provide a place for a suitcase, a bedside table, or a clock. -Single room key provided. We were instructed to leave the room key at the front desk so that more that one guest could access our room. Not terrible, just peculiar. I did not sleep a wink in the room because of the broken air conditioning and the noise from the street and parties around the hotel. The hotel manager was very courteous and responsive in the morning. He would not cut anything from the room price. Because, I had not seen any ability for hotel staff to solve problems effectively, I made a reservation at another hotel that morning and left the Sumahan. One *could* have a pleasant stay at the Sumahan, I would advise to treat the experience as you would a mom and pop bed and breakfast. Quality and consistency are just not provided, but you will be in a beautiful location and you may get lucky and not have a problem.

Reviews.Title: “Luxury in many ways”
Reviews.Author: thefashioneditor
Reviews.Content: Stayed in a junior suite at the Sumahan for the first week of a 3-week trip to Turkey, wanting a great view, room to spread out and a quiet retreat from big-city noise at the end of the day. The hotel delivered, providing one of the most luxurious stays (and best night's sleep) we have ever enjoyed while traveling. The windows from our room, Terabya, provided blow-away views of the Bosphorus and the contemporary furnishings and soothing interior felt more like a residence than a hotel. A few points: yes, it is a distance from Sultanhamet, where you'll likely be spending at least a few days of your trip and the complimentary ferry best serves visits to Dolmabache Palace, the Istanbul Modern Museum (reccomended), and Taksim. But it's a cinch to take the Cengelkoy town ferry to it's final stop from which you can easily walk or take the tram to Hagia Sofia, the Grand Bazaar, etc. We were the first guests to try the Sumahan's just-opened hammam and highly recommend the experience (and you can buy the mohair mitt, peshtemals and white copper bowl -- great gifts -- at Dervis at the Grand Bazaar, and color block rugs similar to those in the hotel at Kurtoglu, close by Dervis). Note: Anticipating a jet-lagged fog we arranged for a car (110 euro) to pick us up at the airport upon arrival; had we known how smooth the entry into Turkey would be, how well-organized and language friendly the airport and the quality and quality of taksi drivers, we would have done that instead and saved the extra 40 lira for two glasses of wine (!!!) on the terrace. Kordon restaurant is great for a first dinner and likely the view, the nightly fireworks across the water and vibe of the whole Sumahan-Kordon compound will blow away the sticker shock for the OK food so on another night, have one of the delightful staff make a reservation at Korfez.

Reviews.Title: “Romantic, but not quite out of the way approach to Istanbul”
Reviews.Author: Tershes
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Sumahan last July at the peak of tourist season. We only managed to book 4 out of 8 days at the Sumahan so our trip to Istanbul was split at two locations (the Sumahan was booked). At the time the Sumahan was not a top rated but I heard about it from a friend. You can look at it as a plus or a minus its distance from old Istanbul. But that time of year I looked at it as a major plus being away from the hustle & bustle of Istanbul. We looked at it as a nice daily retreat from spending the day in Istanbul. The views of Istanbul looking down the Bosphorus are incredible. The Sumahan is located at a bend of the Bosphorus giving you incredible views up and down the Bosphorus. The little town were it was located was a nice contrast from busy Istanbul. We felt totally safe walking around the area around the hotel. We had many romantic dinners at the various waterfront restaurants walking distance from the hotel. The fresh seafood at the restaurants around the hotel was excellent. The ferry service provided by the hotel was kind of lacking but taking the public transportation from the city dock was no problem at all. After 20 minute or so scenic ferry you were in Istanbul. The facility was very unique. It had a very trendy feel to it with its dÃ©cor and lighting. It use to be a cannery at one time and renovated to this gorgeous property. With that being said in order for them to get the best usage of space while maintaining the integrity of the shell of the building they had to use a lot of interior steel construction. I read one of the negative comments about this property being the noise from other rooms due to the steel lofts and stairs founds in some rooms. I personally did not notice the noise being an issue. We stayed in one of the loft rooms which had 2 bathrooms with the one on the second floor being a traditional Turkish hammam. The first floor had overstuffed sectional couch with French doors that opened out to a grassy area where we sat in Adirondack chairs, ate fresh fruit, sipped on beverages watching the busy ship traffic on the Bosphorus. There was a spiral staircase leading to the second floor. The bedroom was also on the second floor. What was nice about the bedroom was you saw the water from the bed and a nice sunset over the hills on the European side of Istanbul. The room service and the bar service was excellent. The hotel staff was very courteous and helpful. I would go back in a heartbeat. If you want something very romantic, off the beaten path (but not too far of the path), stay at the Sumahan.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel, shame about...”
Reviews.Author: swissmodern
Reviews.Content: The Sumahan looks good, is in a beautiful location but 2 things overshadowed the above. We stayed in one of the duplex on the ground floor (and most expensive rooms). What you don't realise is that you have another room above you, above your bed. And that the soundproofing is virtually non-existant. We got woken up every morning by our upstairs neighbours, shuffling about or using the toilet & shower. Also, the hotel offers their boat to ferry you across. BUT only at 9am & 6pm to the spot nearest to the city centre and at 9.30am, 10.30 & 1.30 to the side opposite the hotel. Otherwise you have to pay $$$ for it. We wanted it around 11-12, so had to take the river bus with the locals. For the money the hotel cost, you would expect it to be at your convenience, and free. So... we won't go back...

Reviews.Title: “Magic on the Bosporus”
Reviews.Author: Mr_FantasticMC
Reviews.Content: Sumahan on the water was hands down the single best experience my wife and I have had staying at a hotel. The staff, the views, the decor, the breakfast, everything was just excellent. The best part was in the end it didn't cost me a fortune to get this close to heaven; I've spent twice the money for so much less! This small boutique hotel absolutely captures the charm of Istanbul and boasts some of the greatest Bosporus views in Turkey. From the moment you set foot in the room the ocean envelops you. Chocolates on the table, fireplace to keep you warm, hamam-style bathroom. I must be dreaming. Now, shivering back in Northern VA, I think I was. Alright, enough praise then, I also have some tips if you do choose to stay at Sumahan. The rooms really do make for different experiences. We initially got a loft suite but found it was on the ground floor with only a small window looking out from the upper floor. These may be better for parents who want some separation from kids or for summer-time guests who can just walk outside to take in the views. For us, the deluxe room offered the most affordable way to the magic on the water. The junior & executive suites look to offer the same experience. Dinner initially was to take place at the hotel's posh Kordon fish restaurant, but we made a last minute switch over to Cengelkoy iskelesi, about a five minute walk down the street from Sumahan, after finding some great reviews about it. Not disappointed. Overall there's really nothing more to be said. The best experience for the best value in Istanbul. Love you Sumahan!
